job_title: Member Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA

cons: Adherence team doesn’t let you breathe

job_title: Interpreter Services Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great opportunity Good Team Room for growth
cons: I don't have any cons to report

job_title: Scrum Master in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are some nice people there
cons: The management has no idea what they are doing, they are literally running around in circles. Their turn over in my first week of working there were like 6 people. They are always hiring and firing. The company is fragile yet they want to do things in a agile way. The entire company needs a face lift. They let me go because I had to finish the job of someone else that they fired, and I was simply thrown into his work with no understanding of what exactly needed to be done. I was also ask to take on, an additional role for another department, but expected to be paid the same. The company did not even have the decency to let me know that they had fired me. My recruiter sent me a text, letting me know that they had let me go. Most of the people I worked with was walking on egg shell. Do yourself a favor and run. I don't know how this company is still running.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There are no Pros working for this company other than being employed.
cons: Horrible company, no work life balance. Forced to work weekends and Overtime while being salary. Company is all over the place. Folks in Management that have no idea how to manage. Biggest mistake leaving my previous job for LA Care

job_title: Customer Service I in Los Angeles, CA

cons: There is no support they after you are done with your test they throw you on the phone and provide little to none support. I feel awful for the member they are they one that suffer due to lack of team support!

job_title: IT Technician in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Politics and bureaucracy, but great coworkers
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great mission, excellent benefits (great medical /dental/vision, high tuition reimbursement, healthcare and dependent FSA, parental leave can improve though), great coworkers, excellent diversity.  I worked for a great team, had excellent work/life balance, and we were able to work from home.
cons:
Decision making is in the hands of a few and it's a top down management culture, which leads to poor collaboration amongst departments and limited opportunity to grow skillets. Highly regulated environment with more and more mandates coming from government entities without funding, which leads to overworked staff and key projects being delayed that would really improve business processes. 

Limited room for career growth and innovation. Leaders not experts in their domain, which leads to messy decisions being made that need a lot of cleanup work. Low salaries compared to other health plans.

job_title: Account Manager III in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits Work from home
cons: Toxic workplace/department Toxic Management Directors and Managers are allowed to mistreat employee Micromanagement

job_title: Service Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The people/department teams and that's it.
cons: Too many office politics. It took *years* for a toxic and incompetent Director to be dismissed (she eventually quit before they let her go) but a LOT of people left our department because of her, and many went on LOA or went to HR to complain of the toxic environment she was creating and NO ONE did anything to correct the situation. I eventually quit myself because I could no longer stand working under her under that kind of pressure. No flexibility and not progressive/not open to change or suggestions for increasing productivity and developing a better work/life balance. The company still operates like it was in the 1950s, maybe because upper management is from that era.

job_title: Community Health Worker II in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Like a sour patch..starts off sweet and then sour!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pay and benefits are good
cons: Keep your sanity don't do it. They prompt based on friendships. The noise about the Sr Sup is true. Didnt believe it until I experienced her. She's not easy to work with. And if you speak up you will be targeted, and experience micro aggressions. You'll have to quit before something is done. The mandatory overtime, you have no say. They'll add time to your already fixed schedule or require you to work on your off day so don't make plans or have a routine outside of work. The company cares more about the community then their employees mental health. Procedure changes happens way too often. With no grace period to learn nor time set aside to learn. Under staffed with back to back calls. They offer a lot of great programs but not available to all staff. If you're looking to join the call center give yourself a time to get in and get out. If not to a different department out the company. It's not mentally safe!

job_title: Grievance and Appeals Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Friendly Staff, Great Training and Pay
cons: No Cons, Not applicable currently

job_title: Customer Care Specialist I in Los Angeles, CA
pros: pay is ok. benefits are good; can't think of anyone else
cons: very poor management, will ridicule you for doing your job and what is beyond your control; very critical at grading your calls, also very unfair when it's not even your fault. there is a high turnover rate here, most cubicles are empty within days. LA Care also doesn't "care" about their patients' providers switching on them every other day, i feel bad for the members that would call; so many discrepancies. DO NOT WORK HERE, please I urge you, no matter how good the pay may seem, it's not worth it. It's like signing up for a job like at Amazon but at a health plan call center instead; very low-budget company.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits and potential growth within the organization.
cons: Micro management and too many supervisors.

review_title: It's evolving rapidly, and it's an exciting time to work here
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you want an interesting and rewarding work experience knowing that what you do will really help others then this is the place for you. There's lots of diversity and recently leadership rolled out an employee fitness program that makes it fun to move more. And there is a different restaurant that comes in every day so you can buy lunch on premises. As far as benefits we have good ones, the pay is fine for most jobs, we get PTO instead of sick or vacation days which lets you use it without pinpointing what you did on your time off. The retirement plan and match is pretty good. We're going through huge changes because of Obamacare and its an exciting time to be at L.A. Care. It's evolving rapidly into a new and different organization. Kinda of like a bud blossoming.
cons: Not managing changes well. Right now there is a lot of hiring going on which is good, but because we've run out of space it means people are having to move and sometimes into smaller spaces. So there's a bit of upheaval. The CEO is leaving and we just got a new HR head who's trying to prove himself so there's some adjustment to make. He was hot on not wearing open toed shoes recently. Once all the dust settles next year we should be stronger than ever.

review_title: Good company but some groups are not collaborated

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Initially we had a dynamic executive management - lean and mean and dedicated to the mission and growth / development of the company and totally committed to the health and well being of the member beneficiaries. I loved my employees and co workers. Heaven...
cons: Over the years it has spiraled down to a top heavy, micro-managed, 2 faced, back stabbing company that has continually used favoritism, hired minimally qualified people to oversee those who have more education and experience than they do, and some of the senior management have gone so far as to make false acusations to get people to quit or be fired so they can be replaced with a friend or family member. They will even threaten the good managers with disciplinary action if they don't throw an employee under the bus. Going to HR is useless - even as middle management because they do not care what is legal or ethical - it is all CYA.

review_title: When I went to EEOC in Downtown L.A for file a complaint, The inspector already knows it Corrupt and Toxic place.

job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Experience with Medi-Cal and Medicare Business
cons: Poor Culture and issues with upper management

review_title: Working at LA Care in General
job_title: Director/In Operations in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The mission, vision and values I believe in. We serve underserved and vulnerable populations in a managed care business model. We are now serving Medi-Medi members and disabled members and with the passing of the Affordable Care Act we will serve lots more members in the coming years.
cons:
-There is very little room for career growth in most departments
-The management team is stifled by the executive team in general, communication between the two sets is poor
-Fiefdom hood is the way the organization is run
-We say we are ethical, and we are trained every year on ethics and doing the right thing, but upper management rarely does what they say management and employees should do
-You really aren't allowed to express new and creative and smart ways of doing things and accomplishing one's goals or department objectives, it's a dictatorship mentality, so as long as one understands that, they can be happy under those rules. You are taught to have employees fear you.
-The pay and benefits are low compared to our competitors. Executives make a lot but not management or employees, yet it's all public dollars.

job_title: Provider Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Pretty good pay, potential to get pay incentives
cons: Micromanaging, terrible managers, mandatory overtime.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: None at this point, things are only getting worse.
cons: I urge anyone and everyone to not come work here. This company cares nothing about its employees. No matter how well one performs, LA Care always finds a way to demoralize you and punish you. They care nothing about you personally, they will work you until you can’t physically or mentally take it anymore. Their lack of competent leaders creates an environment where you MUST work mandatory overtime, all the time. They make it almost impossible to plan for a day off, let alone a week of vacation. You are never praised, and only criticized. There is so much turnover here and that’s a very clear sign of how poorly managed this place is. So if you already have a job and are thinking of leaving your current job to come here, DON’T DO IT! You will regret it.

review_title: RN Case Manager - worst nurse job I've ever had
job_title: RN Case Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
-Beautiful modern offices in downtown L.A.
-Very earnest & well intentioned mission
-Very diverse, matches demographic it serves
-Pretty decent pay & benefits - generous vacation accrual  
-GREAT I.T. department 
-They give new(ish) nurses a chance to do CM & make the big bucks - which is both a pro and a con. Good to have fresh young faces in CM nursing but read the cons section!
cons:
-Growth too rapid for management to take the time to hire and screen well-qualified applicants with relevant experience, resulting in very high turnover, especially with nurses
-Obvious ethnic favoritism going on. No one would say it out loud, but it was quite clear that one group dominated this department and hired their friends and family
-Very green, inexperienced and young nurses acting as trainers and supervisors to older, more experienced nurses - that's common in this industry, but this was pretty disastrous 
-Creepy corporate HR department - stiff, cold corporate robots who read from scripts and have dead souls.

review_title: Great for Sheep; Bad for Progress
job_title: Utilization Management in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The company often offers overtime and has a decent pay rate for people lacking experience.
cons:
Upper management is composed of inconsistent authoritarians. If you are looking for a job just to make money and not care about reality, this is for you.

If you truly want to make a difference within the healthcare system, I would not bother applying. Upper management only cares about saving themselves and making sure they are not the ones to lose their paycheck.

Your suggestions for improving efficiency will go ignored.

If you know anyone that has Medi-CAL and is not receiving the care they need, it is because not everyone is consistent and up-to-date with all the types of medical changes happening every day/month/year. Departments within the company often get confused about what the guidelines are because nearly every guide is out-dated.

review_title: Get it together and your employees will be loyal!
job_title: Member Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They have awesome benefits, incentives and rewards for their employees. The pay is pretty good.
cons: Overtime is mandatory and everyday!! The micromanaging is ridiculous. Every second of every minute is accounted for. They monit or how long your bathroom or water breaks are! They count your 15 minute breaks to the last second, so you'd better not be 20 seconds late! Supervisors and leads walk around with walkie talkies checking on staff to make sure they are working and on the phones.

review_title: They offer you benefits but in reality it's just to hook you to say "yes".
job_title: Member Services Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Stable work if you do not have many errors or discrepancies on your calls. Located in Downtown L.A., accessible to major freeways. You are typically off Saturday's and Sunday's. Occasionally you will work on Saturdays.
cons:
A lot of micro-managing. Health benefits are just a promise to Member Services Reps. They will not give you benefits unless you have a clean attendance record, and move to Member Services Rep. 1 status. They never tell you this during the hiring process. There are many employees that have been there a year and still do not get health benefits and they are full-time. The only employees that get health benefits are the upper management staff. It is unfair and ironic for a 'health care" company NOT to provide that to all employees.

Training is horrible! The Trainers confuse you and are not prepared nor have an agenda of what they need to teach you. A lot of "lecturing" involved from one Trainer in particular. It seems that she's been there too long and is there to just collect a paycheck.

job_title: Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nice people and diverse workforce.  Salary scale is high so negotiate accordingly. Benefits are good.
cons: Watch out for temp jobs or jobs of limited duration.  Understand your job title-- even if you have lots of experience and education you may end sitting in a small, noisy cubical. HR won't explain your position level to you and may actively obscure where you will be in the hierarchy.  Lots of BS re how thrilled they are with your resume but then they only offer you a low level position.  Many hires from the East Coast who aren't particularly qualified, maybe friends of the department head from back home who want to come to California.   Location is abysmal-- those East Coasters want to play NYC instead of locating somewhere where its easy for everyone to commute. The elevators don't work so you will spend lots of time waiting for them.

job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
LA Care has a new CEO, John Baackes (named Insurance CEO of the Year by the Los Angeles Business Journal). His mission is to restructure LA Care to better prepare us for the increasingly complex – healthcare and regulatory environment created by the Affordable Care Act--- while ensuring that our members receive the best quality service available. This happening at the same time that LA Care is growing so fast is both challenging and rewarding! 

The employees are the kindest and most supportive that I've worked with anywhere--- and I've been both full-time and consulting for the past 25 years!
cons: In the past, there's been lots of redundant efforts and a general silo mentality that should be helped by the restructuring.

job_title: Authorization Tech in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Incentives (parking and production), dress code and awesome benefit package
cons: LocatioN: mid down downtown L. A. Tons of traffic no matter time of day. Construction in the area  which causes more traffic. The recruiting dept (now) is unresponsive even if you use to work there and are qualified. They do not return calls/emails and give you the run around when you finally can catch them on the phone. The low ball you on the salary as well. Start you off at the minimum pay within that grade no matter the experience. I wanted to come back and work due to the great benefit package and the incentives but the current recruiting dept has turned me completely off

review_title: treat this company as a temporary opportunity
job_title: Payer Contracts Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: annual raises are a bit higher than other health plans, a good place to use a stepping stone in your career in the health insurance industry. relatively new CEO has been proactive in making sure things improve (although it has yet to trickle down)
cons: benefits progressively got worse (replaced 401a plan with social security), Provider Network Management department (formerly Provider Network Operations) is run by idiots. COO has absolutely no idea what he is doing and who works under him. management to executives all have minimal experience in their actual functions. the department is solely held up by experienced employees who inevitably leave to find better jobs because they have industry expertise/knowledge. the employees who are left behind are the ones who are only hanging on to a job because management does not know what they are doing.

review_title: My experience has been mostly positive - a great group of people to work with and for; challenging but limited growth.
job_title: Department Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I love the people and the fact that we're all working for a good cause.  The vibe is mostly positive and people are willing to help each other.  It's stable employment and there are lots of opportunities for learning and creating your own niche.
cons: New and improved procedures and policies take a long time to implement.  The hierarchal structure is changing but as it is now, there is limited opportunity for advancement.  Starting salaries are being investigated and are currently low by comparison.

job_title: Project Liaison in Los Angeles, CA
pros: L.A. Care Health Plan is a company with a definite mission, a public agency which is charged with the task of ensuring numerous patients which other plans will not take or sign up.  The organization is thoroughly focused on achieving this mission.
cons: L.A. Care Health Plan is weighed down by the populations it services.  For example, its providers network for both medical services and pharmaceuticals is very narrow because of the low reimbursements which it can pay.  These present challenges when trying to ensure services to clients.

review_title: Could be better, hope for more
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Compensation is fair; ok benefits, nice building, telecommute flexibility for some departments. Nice people in my team--who are courteous, professional and capable.
cons: Incompetent and indifferent HR, rarely seen in similar sized corporations. Staff needs to improve their basic computer/tech literacy--yes, including some in IT. Many need to work on their email etiquette as well. Major politics especially within upper management. Meaningless back-stabbing at the director/senior director level...utter disgrace and childishness.

job_title: Case Management Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Nurses are mostly nice!
cons: They say one thing do another! They expect nurses to come on site when supposed to be work from home. When you come in your still expected to stay on top of your cases makes no sense with the commute and being on site so not being able to work. Very micro managed. Very over worked, salary is decent but after the work load/ cases and hours spent not worth the salary. Nurses not respected or appreciated at all!  Work not apprecitaed with nurses. Unreslistic expectations. They need to do what everyone else provides fully remote! Get with the times its all remote now!!! And either pay higher salary or dont work nurses to their deaths. VERY HIGH TURN OVER!!!!! VERY VERY HIGH! No one stays!!! Director & Management is the worst.

job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A great place for someone have less skills or knowledge of healthcare to stay here.  Good benefit as they always say no matter how incompetent you're.   If you are related to a senior manager in any form, even better you can stay as long as you can without performance or making mistakes.    Sorry to the tax payers!
cons: Unproductive, administrative inefficiency, low quality and highly unorganized.    I don't understand why top level management doesn't realize the mess system dysfunction has caused tax payers' money wasting in many ways, including high employees turnover, wrong enrollment and overpay claims... etc.

job_title: Data Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Structured Work hours
Healthy education driven Culture
Organizational Mobility (able to change between departments and positions given qualifications)
Good benefits in relation to private companies, competitive salary compensation.
Open to new acquiring new tools to improve existing processes and ideas
cons:
Many older staff, entrenched thought process and methods in some individuals that have to be found and targeted rather than looking for self-improvement.
Transitional Period, can be good or bad, lots to do, lots of pitfalls as well
Lack of technical expertise and knowledge in some departments

review_title: Have no complaints; I needed a job in a down economy and they hired me, which gives me a great deal of loyalty.
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The benefits are quite good. They have a reputation for not paying as well as other companies but the benefits help balance it out. Plus you work to help people who need help, and that's a good feeling.
cons: Sometimes we don't always know where we are going because of external forces, but I feel we will be just fine after Obamacare is all implemented and the dust settles.

review_title: Great people to work with...Management & HR not so much
job_title: Helpdesk Technician in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people to work with, good atmosphere
cons: Management at all levels is horrible!!! Management often plays favorites giving promotions to less qualified employees, if management doesn't like you or has any problems with you, they can and will conspire with HR to terminate you. The HR department does not support the the employees at all, but will side with manage. Once terminated, HR will do anything it can to deny you unemployment benefits.

review_title: Good learning site but managers lack skills
job_title: Program Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits, workload is average, and the industry is secure.
cons: Management has a "Clique" of brown-nosers and you must befriend them to get ahead. Many  managers are promoted because they are all talk and made friends with the clique. But few  have ever taken formal supervisor or management training.  People on other floors treat you like a stranger and can be rude.

review_title: Wow! and I've worked at top-rated companies (including a Fortune Top 10 Places to Work)
job_title: Just Over V Mos On the Job, In I T in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Super-inspiring mission. Modest pay levels. Standard PTO benefits are the best I've ever had - don't have to be a contractor to take time off at amounts that fit my values. Attracts tech people who care about people and have above-average EQ and social skills (NFL Media and Age of Learning were somewhat similar). Some smart, wise top execs (have just met 3 of them). Culture of authenticity and let's focus on the members. Actually celebrates diversity and encourages folks to contribute what all they have/are inspired to (I've proposed to teach a communication course). Does casual Friday everyday in July and August. Great location for public transport. Haven't seen any fragile ego high schoolishness in the culture. They value people - little touches like reimbursement for using your personal cell phone for company business. Makes it easier for love/passion-driven people who come to work here because of the mission to on-goingly love the org. That's a great energy source. I'm the only one left in the office this late.... I take L.A. Care labeled gear on vacation because I'm proud of this mission and this org of people.
cons: It's an org in evolution right now -- grew fast and needs processes to fit its actual size.

review_title: Great organization serving a big need
job_title: Operations in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The mission of the organization drew me here.  Working with smart, dedicated individuals at every level of the organization keeps me energized.  The vast majority of employees are trying to do the best they can to serve the population that we support.
cons: The commute to downtown LA can be a grind if you don't use public transportation but the company does have a transportation allowance to offset the cost.

job_title: Anonymous in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I think it depends on the department you are in, but my experience here has been nothing but positive. I work directly with the members and have had nothing but support from upper management. 

Pay, benefits (best I have received so far), co workers, and option to work from home.
cons: Because it is a non-profit, everything is micromanaged (ex: even what you print.. however, this makes sense as budgets need to be honored)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The best reasons to work there are the benefits (medical , PTO and tuition reimbursement.)  Also they offer telecommuting positions that make it nice to work from home.  Overall, people are friendly and helpful.
cons: Too many changes all at once.  Management doesn't know what employees do yet make changes to workflows without consulting staff. Lack of support from management and follow-thru.

job_title: Grievances & Appeals Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good location, good benefit package, PTO, fantastic facility, good mission.   The employees that are down in the trenches are the part of the of the agency. Those that are on the ground and working closely to the members take their responsibilities very seriously.
cons: Plagued with cronyism, nepotism, higher management not very honest and completely detached form reality.  They have gotten form the original mission of the agency. Top heavy management and very political.

review_title: It's Like Stepping Back In Time - Not A Progress Company
job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The company likes to have parties.
cons:
1.  Employees are not interested in changing processes with innovative technology solutions.  Employees prefer status quo.

2.  Employees do not support the project management discipline.  There is no tracking of budgets and projects are never completed on time.  If you want to sit around and not get any work done and work with a lot of people who are not up to speed on the latest technology, then this is the place for you.

3.  It's a mom and pop shop where there is much favoritism.

4.  Management promotes people they like who are not qualified for the job.

review_title: LA's answer to helping the underprivileged
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Mission and goals are truly considered in every aspect of work, and there are opportunities for growth.
cons:
The business has become more top heavy and a bureaucratic feel is creeping in. There are still some members who slip through the cracks of red tape.
Some upper management staff are more privileged than others giving a feeling of  "favoritism."

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Long Beach, CA
pros: The mission brought me to L.A. Care. Many colleagues are genuine, supportive, and competent.
cons: Managerial confusion, disciplining arbitrarily and inconsistently, inexperienced and ineffective leadership. Left/right hand not on same page.Cart before horse syndrome. Singling out individuals for policy violations (discriminatory). Working at L.A. Care is now demoralizing and depressing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
They promote promotions within the organization and applying to internal positions
They are growing the more and more positions become available
If you are hard worker, you will be praised
I have a work life balance and do not work on the weekends
There are many activities we do together as an organization
cons:
I do truly love working here
Healthcare is growing so some people have left for other companies

HOSTILE ENVIRONMENT AND COVERUP-this company only supports the management, never the employee...so good luck!

job_title: RN Care Manager in Gurgaon, Haryana

cons: Manageoand leadership changes frequently.  They are trying to combine disease management with case management and now add Transition of Care to one job title  (Care Manager). In addition to meeting regulatory requirements,  deadlines are almost impossible to meet.

job_title: Senior Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great enrty level staff, good competitive salary, paid time off is sufficient and there is a good incentive bonus structure.
cons: Toxic work environment that can be fueled by gossip and inuendo. Everyone thinks they can do everyone elses job better when in reality they are playing hot potato with blame and criticism.

job_title: Senior Technical Recruiter in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: Good people to work with and establish relationships. A Target across the street. Smart individuals would hone and develop there skills and move on to an organization that may appreciate them.
cons:
Mismanagement by leadership at the helms of this sinking ship. More reorganizations and layoffs are upcoming. 

I hired 175+ individuals for this one prestigous organization. I was bullied out of my position. I was smart and saw the writing on the wall where I found a more appealing and people oriented organization to hire technology talent.

job_title: Member Services Representative in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: A good company to start in terms with learning Health Care,
cons: Salary is very low, very difficult to grow with in,  no incentives offered to assist with low salary,  H.R put a freeze on salary increases when certain departments were told their would be one. company is very unorganized.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Salary, above average benefits, good retirement, competent and hard working colleagues, interesting work
cons: HR policies are loaded to favor management and do not have an appeal process to settle disputes between an employee and manager, managers get away with mistreatment of employees, lots of arrogant managers who want things done their way.

review_title: Nice people - poor management ( at the time, it's mostly new now)
job_title: Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Almost everyone was great to work with and tried to be as helpful as they could. Nice hard-working people. Benefits were ok.
cons: The company was very compartmentalized and the right hand rarely knew what the left was doing. There is new management now...so who knows how things are. Too big to fail...

job_title: Lead Medical/RN Management Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good Salary, good resume builder
cons: Fragmented Executive decisions on how to manage the business of Health Care. Staff not committed, no training for any level position. IT not able to handle growth and no equipment upgrades

job_title: Project Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: CEO is very knowledgeable and cares about the employees. Great work/life balance.  Worthy mission, and concern for the community.  Attractive offices located near DTLA.
cons: Headquarters is crowded so elevators take long.  Certain Cliques get ahead.

job_title: Healthcare Office Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The company mission is admirable and they help a lot of low income people in Los Angeles get health insurance. Co-employees are friendly.
cons:
What I find to be a con, you may like, so here goes:
- Interview - I had a gang interview with several "supervisors" and one "manager" in the room. They read questions from a paper and then wrote down my answers. Very unprofessional and stressful. If they don't write down what you say and how they respond to you, they will later deny it ever came up (i.e. salary requirements.)
- Job Offer - They waited 3 MONTHS to offer me the job. Then they lowballed me. When I reminded them of the salary requirements during the interview, they denied they ever agreed to them. I found out later that several other employees were also lowballed and had to wait months for an offer. I guess they figure if you're still out of work, you're desperate and you'll take anything. Which I, like a sucker, did. Very bad way to start out a new job. And the job offer comes like this - the salary is $XX.XX per hour, final offer, take it or leave it. Very nasty way to make an offer, IMO.
- Exempt / Hourly / Per-Diem - Be VERY CAREFUL when getting hired that you know which classification they put you in. I thought I was going to be "Exempt," but when the offer came in "hourly," I was like - wait, what? Here's why - they want you to document every single little thing you do to justify each and every minute of every hour. Make a business phone call? Write it down (i.e., called hospital, 3 minutes.) Type an email? Write it down. (i.e. typed email to XYZ Hospital - 4 minutes.) Get the picture? Can you say MICRO-MANAGEMENT??? And co-workers with the same job title told me they typically had to work 12 hours a day just to be able to document 8 hours of billable time. Sounds like a Labor Standards violation to me.
- Parking - You have to pay for your own parking. Not only is it an ordeal to drive in extreme rush hour traffic to downtown L.A. every day, with a 8:30 AM non-flexible start time, but then you have to pay for your own parking in their lot for the luxury of working there.
- Health Insurance - SUCKS! I mean, what? They ARE a health Insurance Company!!! But they don't even offer their own plans to employees! If you are single, it's not too expensive, but if you have a family, count on $700+ per month out of your paycheck for a decent Blue Cross HMO or Kaiser.  This was WAY TO EXPENSIVE for me, as I was lowballed in salary (see above.)
- Training - All new employees must attend their mandatory 3 day training class in the "company" (not actual job training) before ever setting foot in their actual job. What a waste. So if you don't like the job (as I didn't), you wasted all that training time for nothing. I think it would be better to have employees attend that training after their first week or two on the job, to eliminate all the folks that will quit when finding out their job sucks.
- After company training - No one gave me instructions. I didn't know where to go. I showed up for work, and no one knew where I should sit, who my manager was, or what I was supposed to do. No computer ready for me, no desk. And the people who interviewed me were all out of the office. The on-the job training was by co-employees with the same job title who kept telling me how much they hated their job and complained about everything company related. Way to start a new employee out!.
- Environment - Cubicles are tightly packed around each and every floor, with supervisors constantly seeing what you are doing 24/7. You can hear a pin drop, or a fart from 5 cubicles away. Employees are scared to talk. People whispered on the phone. You could hear keyboard keys from 3 cubicles over. Seriously, it is the quietest work environment I have ever been in in my life. To some folks, this may be a plus. But to me, it was enough to drive you insane. I heard that the folks in the customer service building were very loud (obviously), and also the IT department, but where I was, crickets. Not for me. Felt like a slave. Every time I went to the bathroom, everyone knew. I need a bit more freedom, sorry.
- The job itself - Much different than what I was told it would be on the interview. I felt like the actual job was much worse, and they knew it, so they hid the details in their advert and the interview. To me, it was a bait and switch. 
- Quitting - No one cares. No exit interview, no one from HR called to see why I quit. Maybe if someone called and I said all of this to them instead of typing it here, they could have implemented changes so new employee turnover is not so high. Have you noticed - they don't even respond to these bad reviews on Glassdoor? That should tell you something.

job_title: Authorization Clerk in Monrovia, CA
pros: Busy environment,  makes day go much faster. Professional,  fast pace. Much room for growth.
cons: If you live in the outer LA areas , traffic is horrible both to and from . at least 2 1/2 hour drive. I started at 8am and would live my house at 5:20 am , most of the time i would arrive 15 minutes early. But there were times I would be late due to traffic.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

Management has forced employees to use the new core IT system since last year despite many serious bugs and its inability to process claims, causing major employee dissatisfaction.  Current CEO has announced his departure and has mentally left the building

review_title: Great benefits, and compensation. Poor culture.

review_title: not the best place to work
job_title: Behavioral Health Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: downtown locations, able to use public transportation, good benefits, decent pay
cons: unethical practices, providers hate la care and take every opportunity to tell you how much they dislike company, unprofessional directors, poor management, too many computer EHR systems to manage,

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Average benefits, seen better. Good place if you just want to go to work and slack off most of the time and get paid. Great pay, I mean wipes out the competition based on the responsibilities and quality standards expected from you. Easy going management.
cons: It seems like most don't know anything about healthcare, maybe a little bit about their specific position (do it wrong most times). Most positions are very limited in the sense that it is very specific to one task. They don't offer quality training for employees, especially to understand how their position contributes to Managed Care in general; which I think is crucial if you hire unexperienced employees. Most times it’s repetitive and not a lot of work per individual, which leave employees bored out of their mind. They promote employees internally to high impact positions, even though the person doesn’t know how to do the job (remember they don’t train properly), this results in that person in a high impact position doing poor work making it harder for other employees to carry out theirs. Systems are the worst; I’ve seen better systems used in the 80’s. Very unprofessional environment and people joke about the members, not even making it anonymous; they actually mention who it is. I REGRET ACCEPTING THEIR OFFER, even though it paid much more than what I used to get doing less work with less responsibility.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Growth.  Constant Change. Restructuring. Passionate staff. Mission driven for vulnerable populations.
cons: Lack of accountability for processes. Missing Service Level Agreements to standardize accountability.  The integrity of some upper management is questionable as to their objective to bring in outside staff instead of mentoring current staff.

review_title: Great benefits and pay, but if looking for growth look elsewhere.
